title: How to Improve Your Home Brew Beer

steps.headline: Boil the mash for shorter times.
steps.description: Many recipes call for a 60 minute boil. After the 60 minute boil, the standard recipe will call for a 10 minute flavoring simmer. Boil the wort for whatever time that gives you the desired mix of aroma, flavor, and bitterness. Hop characteristics are dictated by boiling times. According to the Brewmasters at Brew Supplies, the peak aroma is achieved at about 7 minutes after the start of the boil, and is almost completely lost at 15 minutes. Peak flavor is about 20 minutes into the boil, and is almost completely lost at 40 minutes. All that is left is bitterness, which is fully achieved at approximately 60 minutes. Beer is not intended to have only one of these characteristics. Aroma, flavor, and bitterness are all necessary in their proportion to make the pallet desired.

steps.headline: Put 2 gallons (7.56 liters) of water into a large stock-pot.
steps.description: Bring the water to 155ºF/68.3ºC. Add the malt (this is assuming that you are using the prepared liquid malt, or LME) into the hot water and mix well. Add the aroma hops and bring the mash up to a boil.

steps.headline: After a 7 minute boil, add the flavoring hops and turn down the heat to low for 5 minutes.
Remove the pot from the heat.
Pour 3 gallons of bottled water plus 1 7Lb (3.1 kg) bag of ice into the fermenter bucket.
Pour the mash, through a strainer (sparge), into the fermenter bucket.
Check the temperature of the wort.
steps.description: It should be approximately 70-80ºF/21ºC-26.6ºC, but no higher than 85ºF/29.6ºC.

steps.headline: Pitch in the yeast.
steps.description: Cover the fermenter, and if necessary, install the airlock.

text: Boil the mash for shorter times. Many recipes call for a 60 minute boil. After the 60 minute boil, the standard recipe will call for a 10 minute flavoring simmer. Boil the wort for whatever time that gives you the desired mix of aroma, flavor, and bitterness. Hop characteristics are dictated by boiling times. According to the Brewmasters at Brew Supplies, the peak aroma is achieved at about 7 minutes after the start of the boil, and is almost completely lost at 15 minutes. Peak flavor is about 20 minutes into the boil, and is almost completely lost at 40 minutes. All that is left is bitterness, which is fully achieved at approximately 60 minutes. Beer is not intended to have only one of these characteristics. Aroma, flavor, and bitterness are all necessary in their proportion to make the pallet desired. Put 2 gallons (7.56 liters) of water into a large stock-pot. Bring the water to 155ºF/68.3ºC. Add the malt (this is assuming that you are using the prepared liquid malt, or LME) into the hot water and mix well. Add the aroma hops and bring the mash up to a boil. After a 7 minute boil, add the flavoring hops and turn down the heat to low for 5 minutes.  Remove the pot from the heat.  Pour 3 gallons of bottled water plus 1 7Lb (3.1 kg) bag of ice into the fermenter bucket.  Pour the mash, through a strainer (sparge), into the fermenter bucket.  Check the temperature of the wort. It should be approximately 70-80ºF/21ºC-26.6ºC, but no higher than 85ºF/29.6ºC. Pitch in the yeast. Cover the fermenter, and if necessary, install the airlock.
